choices.text: CMV
HPV
Rubella
Tetanus

questions.text: A 25 y woman is planning to conceive. She is unsure of her childhood vaccination status. Which of the following vaccines should she receive before conceiving?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rubella

  • Pre-pregnancy, if rubella immunization status Is unknown, serological evaluation is done (IgG rubella) and if IgG Rubella is negative, then vaccination with rubella vaccine is recommended.
  • Very important! Conception is to be avoided for 1 month after vaccination with rubella as it is a live attenuated vaccine

Ref: Page no 647, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: 6-10 weeks
12-20 weeks
24-28 weeks
36 – 40 weeks

questions.text: The highest risk of developing congenital varicella syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 12-20 weeks

  • Congenital Varicella Syndrome is characterized by
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cerebral cortical atrophy
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Cicatricial skin lesions

 

  • The highest risk of fetal infection is between 13-20 weeks.

Ref: Page no 1212-1213, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: IgG CMV
CMV specific IgG avidity by enzyme immunoassay
Amniotic fluid for viral culture
Amniotic fluid for CMV nucleic acid amplification testing

questions.text: The gold standard for the diagnosis of fetal infection with CMV is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Amniotic fluid for CMV nucleic acid amplification testing

  • Routine testing for CMV in pregnancy is not recommended
  • If suspicion is there then, the investigation of choice (Gold standard) for fetal infection with CMV is CMV nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT)

Ref: Page no 1212, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Congenital Rubella Syndrome
Congenital Varicella Syndrome
Fetal Parvovirus infection
Fetal Toxoplasma infection

questions.text: Triad of Gregg is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Congenital Rubella Syndrome

Congenital Rubella Syndrome is characterized by Triad of Gregg

  • 3 main systems involved: Eye, Heart, Ear
  • Eye
    • Cataract
    • Retinopathy
    • Microphthalmia
    • Glaucoma
  • Heart
    • Patent Ductus Arteriosus
    • Pulmonary valvular stenosis
    • Coarctation of aorta
    • VSD
    • ASD
  • Ear
    • Sensorineural hearing loss

choices.text: Invasive fetal monitoring
High viral load
Presence of chorioamnionitis
High CD4 count

questions.text: All are risk factors for increased perinatal transmission of HIV except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. High CD4 count

Risk factors for Vertical Transmission:

 

 

Ref: Page no 550, JB Sharma; Textbook of Obstetrics, 1st edition

20%

questions.text: In the absence of anti-retroviral therapy, the risk of perinatal transmission of HIV before 36 weeks pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 20%

In the absence of any intervention, the risk of perinatal transmission is:

 

Ref: Page no 550, JB Sharma; Textbook of Obstetrics, 1st edition

choices.text: Opt in screening
Opt out screening
Screening in high-risk groups
Compulsory screening

questions.text: The National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) recommends which of the following screening approaches for HIV testing in pregnancy in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Opt in screening

  • National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) India, recommends all pregnant women in India (irrespective of risk factors) should be counseled to undergo testing for HIV unless they OPT-OUT of it (Opt out approach)

Ref:  Page no 552, JB Sharma; Textbook of Obstetrics, 1st edition

choices.text: Start antiretroviral therapy (ART) and continue lifelong
Start ART in the 3rd trimester and continue lifelong
Do not start ART till the CD4 count is < 200
Start ART and continue till breastfeeding is stopped

questions.text: A 29y primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic for routine checkup. On investigations she is found to be HIV positive. Her CD4 count is 520. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Start antiretroviral therapy (ART) and continue lifelong

Management of HIV +ve pregnancy

  • Antenatal
  • Test for
    • Other STDs
    • Test for CMV and toxoplasmosis
    • Tuberculosis
    • Fungal and other opportunistic infections
    • Partner/ husband should be tested
  • For prevention of pneumocystis pneumonia: Co-trimoxazole should be started if CD4 count is ≤ 250 cells/mm3 and continued through pregnancy, delivery and breastfeeding as per national guidelines (Dose: Double strength tablet – 1 tab daily).
  • Assess immunization status and update as needed
  • Counseling on impact of HIV on pregnancy and factors influencing the progression of disease and risk of perinatal transmission.
  • CD4 count testing in each trimester
  • Monitor HIV RNA levels monthly after changing/ initiating therapy
  • CBC, LFT and KFT in each trimester
  • Anti-retroviral therapy for all
    • Start at diagnosis (regardless of CD4 count); continue lifelong
    • As per NACO:
      • Initiate lifelong ART in all pregnant women with confirmed HIV infection regardless of WHO clinical stage or CD4 cell count.
      • TDF + 3TC + EFV is recommended as first-line ART in pregnant and breastfeeding women (including pregnant women in the first trimester of pregnancy)
      • Pregnant women detected to be HIV +ve for the first time in labor: Initiated on ART (TDF+3TC+EFV) immediately
      • Also remember the ACOG guidelines (As this has been asked previously in AIIMS) as given in the table below:

 

Ref:

  1. Page no 1249, William’s Obstetrics 2th edition
  2. http://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National_Guidelines_for_PPTCT_0.pdf

choices.text: Administer tocolysis and send CD4 count
Conduct delivery with universal precautions
Initiate anti-retroviral therapy
Immediate cesarean section

questions.text: A 20-year G2 presents to the labor room at 38 weeks in early labor. She is an unbooked patient and on routine investigations is found to be HIV +ve. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Initiate anti-retroviral therapy

 

  • As per WHO and NACO guidelines; Caesarean section is not recommended for prevention of mother-to-child-transmission and is only done for Obstetric Indication
  • Pregnant women detected to be HIV +ve for the first time in labor: Initiated on ART (TDF+3TC+EFV) immediately
  • However; both ACOG and RCOG recommend elective caesarean section in HIV +ve women to reduce the risk of vertical transmission if the viral load is high

Ref: Page no. 1249, William’s Obstetrics 2th edition

http://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National_Guidelines_for_PPTCT_0.pd

choices.text: Termination of pregnancy
Benzathene penicillin 2.4 million units IM single dose
Send fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS)
Repeat VDRL after 2 weeks

questions.text: A 26-year-old test positive for VDRL on routine antenatal investigations. She is 8 weeks pregnant. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Send fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS)

  • Routine testing for syphilis is done in pregnancy by VDRL
  • A positive VDRL needs to be confirmed by FTA-ABS and Treponema pallidum micro-agglutination (MHA-TP) test which are specific
  • Treatment is with Benzathene penicillin 2.4 million units IM single dose

 

Ref: Page no 276, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: 6 weeks
16 weeks
26 weeks
36 weeks

questions.text: Physiological goiter of pregnancy is seen at ____ weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 16 Weeks

  • Glandular hyperplasia and increased vascularity occur during normal pregnancy and cause slight generalized enlargement of the thyroid.
  • This is called physiological goiter
  • Begins in the 4th month
  • Continues till term
  • Regresses by 2 – 3 weeks postpartum
  • The stimulatory effect of hCG causes this enlargement

Ref: Page no 59, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 1st edition

choices.text: Abruptio placentae
Increased risk of abortion
Pre-eclampsia
Placenta previa

questions.text: All are effects of hypothyroidism on pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Placenta previa

Maternal and Fetal Effects of Hypothyroidism

 

Ref: Page no 270, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Sodium valproate
Methimazole
Propylthiouracil
Warfarin

questions.text: Aplasia cutis is associated with which teratogenic drug in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Methimazole

  • Methimazole is a drug used in hyperthyroidism in pregnancy
  • It may be associated with aplasia cutis of the neonate. It is also associated with esophageal or choanal atresia
  • Other drugs that can be given in hyperthyroidism in pregnancy are:
  • Propylthiouracil (preferred especially in the 1st trimester)
  • Carbimazole

Ref: Page no 269, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition, page no 1120, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Retinoic acid
Propylthiouracil
Phenytoin
Methimazole

questions.text: A newborn was noted to have the following lesion on the scalp. Which drug taken in pregnancy could have caused this?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Methimazole

  • This image is of congenital aplasia cutis i.e., congenital absence of the skin usually on the scalp. It is associated with Methimazole use in pregnancy.  (In hyperthyroidism)
  • Propylthiouracil is also a drug used in hyperthyroidism in pregnancy and is considered as the first line drug in pregnancy for hyperthyroidism.
  • Retinoic acid use in pregnancy is associated with Retinoic acid embryopathy: Ventriculomegaly, mal-development of facial bone or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, cono-truncal heart defects and thymic aplasia
  • Phenytoin use in pregnancy is associated with Fetal hydantoin syndrome: Characterized by: Upturned nose, midfacial hypoplasia and Distal digital hypoplasia

 

Ref: Page no 269, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Methimazole in the 1st trimester and Propylthiouracil in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters
Propylthiouracil (PTU) throughout the pregnancy
Propylthiouracil (PTU) in the 1st trimester and methimazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters
Methimazole throughout pregnancy

questions.text: A pregnant patient is diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. Which of the following drugs is considered the safest for the treatment of hyperthyroidism in pregnancy by the American Thyroid association?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Propylthiouracil (PTU) in the 1st trimester and methimazole in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters

 

Explanation:

  • PTU is preferred in the first trimester due to the teratogenic risk of methimazole
  • Propylthiouracil (PTU) has been historically preferred because it partially inhibits the conversion of T4 to T3 and crosses the placenta less readily than methimazole.
  • Methimazole Is associated with a rare methimazole embryopathy, characterized by:
    • Esophageal or choanal atresia
    • Aplasia cutis, a congenital skin defect.
       
  • However, treatment with PTU is associated with a higher risk for liver injury
  • The American Thyroid Association and the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (2011) recommend PTU therapy during the first trimester followed by a switch to methimazole beginning in the second trimester. More recently, the American Thyroid Association recommends PTU therapy through 16 weeks’ gestation but does not make a recommendation regarding switching to methimazole treatment because both agents are associated with adverse effects and the harm from poorer control during the switch is unknown but the better answer to this question is to start with PTU and then switch to methimazole.
  • Transient leukopenia can be documented in up to 10 percent of women taking antithyroid drugs, but this does not require therapy cessation. If fever or sore throat develops, women are instructed to discontinue medication immediately and report for a complete blood count

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Methimazole is not to be given in the 1st trimester due to its teratogenic effects
  • Option B: Although the recent American Thyroid Association guidelines do not mention what is to be given after 16 weeks, the older guidelines specify that in the 2nd and 3rd trimester methimazole should be given.
  • Option D: Methimazole is not given in the 1st trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methimazole Is associated with a rare methimazole embryopathy, characterized by:
    • Esophageal or choanal atresia
    • Aplasia cutis, a congenital skin defect.

 

Ref: Page no 2841, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Subclinical hypothyroidism
Overt hypothyroidism
Subclinical hyperthyroidism
Overt hyperthyroidism

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in her second trimester of pregnancy has a normal TSH but elevated free T4 levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Subclinical hyperthyroidism

 

Explanation: Normal TSH with elevated free T4 suggests subclinical hyperthyroidism (Option C), where the thyroid is overactive but not enough to suppress TSH. Overt hyperthyroidism (Option D) would typically present with a suppressed TSH.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Subclinical Hypothyroidism is characterized by a mildly elevated TSH level with normal free T4 levels. It indicates a mild form of hypothyroidism where the thyroid is beginning to underperform but has not yet resulted in decreased thyroid hormone production. This option does not align with the patient's lab results, which show a normal TSH and elevated free T4.

 

Option B: Overt hypothyroidism is diagnosed when both TSH levels are high, and free T4 levels are low. This condition indicates a significant deficiency in thyroid hormone production. The patient's lab results do not support this diagnosis since her free T4 levels are elevated, not low.

 

Option C: In overt hyperthyroidism, both TSH levels are suppressed (usually below the normal range), and free T4 levels are elevated. This condition indicates a significantly overactive thyroid. The patient's normal TSH level makes this diagnosis less likely compared to subclinical hyperthyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal TSH with elevated free T4 suggests subclinical hyperthyroidism (Option C), where the thyroid is overactive but not enough to suppress TSH. Overt hyperthyroidism (Option D) would typically present with a suppressed TSH.

 

Ref: Page no 1122, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Primary hypothyroidism
Secondary hypothyroidism
Gestational transient thyrotoxicosis
Hyperemesis gravidarum

questions.text: During pregnancy, a woman with no prior history of thyroid disease presents with a low TSH but normal free T4 and free T3 levels. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gestational transient thyrotoxicosis

 

Explanation: Gestational Transient Thyrotoxicosis is characterized by transiently low TSH levels in the first trimester of pregnancy, usually due to the high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which can stimulate the thyroid gland. It typically occurs without significant thyroid dysfunction, and free T4 and free T3 levels remain within normal limits. This condition is usually self-limiting and resolves as pregnancy progresses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Primary Hypothyroidism is characterized by high TSH levels and low free T4 levels, as the primary problem lies in the thyroid gland itself, which is unable to produce sufficient thyroid hormones. This diagnosis does not fit the patient's lab results, which show a low TSH level.

 

Option B: In secondary hypothyroidism, both TSH and free T4 levels are low. This condition is due to a problem in the pituitary gland, which fails to produce enough TSH to stimulate the thyroid. Again, this option does not align with the patient's lab results, as her free T4 and T3 levels are normal.

 

Option D: While hyperemesis gravidarum, a condition characterized by severe nausea and vomiting in pregnancy, can be associated with thyroid function changes, it typically does not cause isolated low TSH with normal free T4 and T3 levels. The thyroid function changes seen in hyperemesis gravidarum are usually a part of gestational transient thyrotoxicosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational Transient Thyrotoxicosis is characterized by transiently low TSH levels in the first trimester of pregnancy, usually due to the high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which can stimulate the thyroid gland. It typically occurs without significant thyroid dysfunction, and free T4 and free T3 levels remain within normal limits. This condition is usually self-limiting and resolves as pregnancy progresses.

 

Ref: Page no 1122, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Fetal goiter and hypothyroidism
Fetal hyperthyroidism
Neonatal diabetes
Congenital heart defects

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of Graves' disease is being treated with methimazole. Which of the following fetal complications is she most at risk for?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fetal goiter and hypothyroidism

 

Explanation: Methimazole use during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester, can lead to fetal goiter and hypothyroidism (Option A).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Fetal hyperthyroidism is more commonly seen if the mother has uncontrolled hyperthyroidism.

 

Option C and D: Neonatal diabetes and congenital heart defects are not typically associated with methimazole use in pregnancy.  Methimazole can cause esophageal or choanal atresia as well as aplasia cutis .

 

Ref: Page no 1120, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition
